body:
https://ruqqus.com/help/rules

If you haven't read this yet, I reccomend you do. I see too many posts from people going:

"WHY DID I GET BANNED FOR SPAMMING NEW"
or
"Why did I get banned for planning a terrorist attack?" 

Ruqqus is a free speech platform, but does have a few rules on posting in compliance with US law. 

I personally don't find the content policy restrictive, but if you've a poster on the fringes, its worth checking out so you dont wake up b&

guild.description:
The official guild for all things Ruqqus.

Rules:

💻 No promotion of other sites that aren't a fork of Ruqqus

🟪 Ruqqus-related only. This is a community dedicated to Ruqqus meta discussion. Content may involve technology and politics but must have ample context in Ruqqus.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

For press releases, visit +RuqqusPress.

For updates and patch notes, visit +changelog.

For ideas and feedback, visit +BetaFeedback

For bug reports, visit +RuqqusBugs

post.title: You should probably read the Ruqqus Content Policy

body:
It's a good thing the policy doesn't define spam in any way, so that "spam" can be used to carry out viewpoint-based discrimination against people we don't like.

EDIT: There's also no rule against "brigading", which is interesting since IIRC several people have been banned for that, including both guildmasters of +WhiteVictimsofBlackCrime.

author.bio:
Oliver from Savannah, Georgia, USA.

How I Ruqqus : 
I use news aggregators like popurls.com and upstract.com. Google news with many and large publishers filtered. I save interesting things to the bookmark manager 'raindrop' to share with y'all!
author.bio_html:
Oliver from Savannah, Georgia, USA.

How I Ruqqus : I use news aggregators like popurls.com and upstract.com. Google news with many and large publishers filtered. I save interesting things to the bookmark manager 'raindrop' to share with y'all!

body:
It says spam is disallowed

Not spamming new, which I've been (perhaps correctly) accused of by users for submitting different articles to different guilds too quickly.

Why don't we ban:

 multi accounts, maybe providing a "post anonymously option" to replace the need,

Vote manipulation and brigading (although that could fall under harrassment)

Or posting in bad faith?

 Direct those users toward voat. 

Maybe I'm niave.

As much as I find the obvious trolling yawn-o-rama, it really plays into their hands to claim to be a free speech platform and then ban people for something that isn't actually against the host country's laws.

All this has done is prove that arbitrary modding is still a thing. If it was left alone they'd eventually get bored and have no evidence that this is just Reddit lite. They'd probably have still stuck with Voat too if their Ruqqus sub didn't get any decent engagement. Did anyone actually go to school or does nobody know how how to deal with annoying edgy kids?

body:
There is a difference about having simply trolling and having sock puppets for spamming, brigading, astroturfing and vote manipulation. If you try to game the site, you should be banned, whatever it’s explicitly in the rules or not, and no amount of pseudo-lawyering will change that.

Reddit-lite? [False equivalence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_equivalence)!

body: Please quote in verbatim the exact part of Ruqqus Tos that prohibits "having sock puppets for spamming, brigading, astroturfing and vote manipulation". We may agree that doing any of that is not great or welcome but strictly speaking it is not against ToS and so it must not serve as a base for a ban. If ToS has holes in it the only acceptable way is for Ruqqus to update them and start enforcing new rules after they are added.

body:
The double-edged sword of being free of censorship is that you have to trust in people to spot the manipulators and the liars without having someone to protect them from it. I don't necessarily trust people to *have* that capacity (or even myself, truthfully) but it's part of the deal.

By all means, call it out - please do. That's what teaches people to question what they see. If it gets deleted before anyone notices, they don't know it's something to look out for.

post.title: You should probably read the Ruqqus Content Policy

body:
>It's a good thing the policy doesn't define spam in any way, so that "spam" can be used to carry out viewpoint-based discrimination against people we don't like.

Not really. Spam needs to be repetitive and unsolicited; so as long as you have someone wanting to hear you *or* your message is unique, it isn't spam, by definition. Note the situation is completely unlike "hate" (a feeling) or "harassment" (subjective).

I do think the admins will eventually need to define spam in the content policy though.

On Amalek: I'm not informed enough on what happened there.

parent.body:
Hypothetically speaking: no, it wouldn't be spam.

But here's the one million dollars question: was he banned for posting those videos there, *or for another reason people are omitting?*

post.body:
https://ruqqus.com/help/rules

If you haven't read this yet, I reccomend you do. I see too many posts from people going:

"WHY DID I GET BANNED FOR SPAMMING NEW"
or
"Why did I get banned for planning a terrorist attack?" 

Ruqqus is a free speech platform, but does have a few rules on posting in compliance with US law. 

I personally don't find the content policy restrictive, but if you've a poster on the fringes, its worth checking out so you dont wake up b&

parent.body:
>It's a good thing the policy doesn't define spam in any way, so that "spam" can be used to carry out viewpoint-based discrimination against people we don't like.

Not really. Spam needs to be repetitive and unsolicited; so as long as you have someone wanting to hear you *or* your message is unique, it isn't spam, by definition. Note the situation is completely unlike "hate" (a feeling) or "harassment" (subjective).

I do think the admins will eventually need to define spam in the content policy though.

On Amalek: I'm not informed enough on what happened there.

Libertarian. Wiccan. Degenerate.

body:
It's not a false equivalence.

The rules (TOS, content policy, other public documentation that can be said to exist as part of a "community ruleset") exist purely to explain what is or is not bannable - they have no other function. This is why they should be as minimal as possible - and it's also why bans for reasons outside the rules are always unacceptable.

Meanwhile, Reddit has been breaching the latter principle for a long time, and you advocating to breach it here. Whilst you may have other reasons for not liking Reddit, for the relevant concern, it is equivalent.

body:
Note: this is my personal opinion, not the admins'.

Brigading is behaviour intended to force a certain discourse in detriment of other competing discourses, and as such it's against the principle of free speech. It's also associated with some behaviours that can be considered harassment, such as sealioning and dogpiling. 

The issue isn't the site those people come from, but rather the intention.

The tricky part is that rules about intentions are usually bad rules, so it's damn hard to create good rules to curb down brigading. So those rules might pop up under different names.

As a side note: no, nobody here is "persecuting Voatfugees". At least I don't think the admins are.

body:
A distinction without a difference, and a generally false statement, because "speech" includes behavior. 

It is a contribution to discourse to upvote or downvote you without making a written statement just as it is a contribution to discourse (if in poor taste, inaccurate, and rather blatantly manipulative) to make that terrible "This Is America" song/video, or to burn a flag. 

These things are all "speech" because they are all parts of discourse, whether they are civilized or not. If this is a free speech platform it needs to act like one.

body:
Assault is criminal behavior. Criminal behavior is still speech, if we're being technical about it. It's excepted from 'free speech' for reasonable reasons. 

**I don't disagree with you that these things are not positive to discourse.  But if it's not in the rules somewhere admins should not be doing jackshit about it.** 

They can change the rules. I'd accept a rule change against spamming, etc (I'd be upset, but grudgingly upset brigading, which I don't think is harmful to discourse), *and then there wouldn't be an issue. * 

Do you understand that it's not the content or nature of the "bad behavior" that makes this is a problem?

author.bio:
Libertarian. Wiccan. Degenerate. 

I don't like you.

body:
The problem I see with disallowing brigading is that it opens up too many doors. Brigading itself is a negative, sure, but making significant efforts to dissuade it creates two things:

- An arms race. This is bad for everyone, bad actors included, but especially for us, with Ruggus' shaky servers.
- The justification to call one more thing bad behavior, and one more after that, which will turn Ruqqus into Reddit or centrist Reddit or Reddit Lite or w/e, This is proven human behavior, normal for moderation, and the way to avoid it is to keep these doors shut. 

Nobody wins.
body_html:
The problem I see with disallowing brigading is that it opens up too many doors. Brigading itself is a negative, sure, but making significant efforts to dissuade it creates two things:

  • An arms race. This is bad for everyone, bad actors included, but especially for us, with Ruggus' shaky servers.
  • The justification to call one more thing bad behavior, and one more after that, which will turn Ruqqus into Reddit or centrist Reddit or Reddit Lite or w/e, This is proven human behavior, normal for moderation, and the way to avoid it is to keep these doors shut.

Nobody wins.

parent.body:
Note: this is my personal opinion, not the admins'.

Brigading is behaviour intended to force a certain discourse in detriment of other competing discourses, and as such it's against the principle of free speech. It's also associated with some behaviours that can be considered harassment, such as sealioning and dogpiling. 

The issue isn't the site those people come from, but rather the intention.

The tricky part is that rules about intentions are usually bad rules, so it's damn hard to create good rules to curb down brigading. So those rules might pop up under different names.

As a side note: no, nobody here is "persecuting Voatfugees". At least I don't think the admins are.

The issue isn't the site those people come from, but rather the intention.

The tricky part is that rules about intentions are usually bad rules, so it's damn hard to create good rules to curb down brigading. So those rules might pop up under different names.

As a side note: no, nobody here is "persecuting Voatfugees". At least I don't think the admins are.

body:
There is no incoherence.

I do think that the mods should update the ToS, more for user’s sake than as a guideline for their action should the need arise (and, disagreeing with you again, it was Voat’s admins’ inaction when facing with people trying to game the site that prevented it to be successful. *It has a large user base than Ruqqus, yet it’s essentially dead*)

And, in this whole brouhaha, the only thing where, IMO, the admins could have done better is that they should have communicated better. I don’t have much issue with moderation outside the rules (which is not the same as censorship) as you do, but I feel better when I get an explanation, even if just to voice my disagreement (as you are doing).

parent.body:
There is no incoherence.

I do think that the mods should update the ToS, more for user’s sake than as a guideline for their action should the need arise (and, disagreeing with you again, it was Voat’s admins’ inaction when facing with people trying to game the site that prevented it to be successful. *It has a large user base than Ruqqus, yet it’s essentially dead*)

And, in this whole brouhaha, the only thing where, IMO, the admins could have done better is that they should have communicated better. I don’t have much issue with moderation outside the rules (which is not the same as censorship) as you do, but I feel better when I get an explanation, even if just to voice my disagreement (as you are doing).

body:
>any other/new accounts you have will also get the same treatment if/when they can identify them as being from a banned user

Based on my experience and research by trial and error (I graduated in computer science, I write code daily etc) this process is not automatic and is heavily dependent on reddit admins human input. I kept creating new accounts that would get suspended within the day, but as soon as I changed the pattern it stopped. They got tired very quickly and depend on mods reporting ban evasion to them a lot.

I agree, transparency is important to build the trust the platform needs to succeed. I wish admins would address the concerns raised so far before transparency tools are available.
body_html:
any other/new accounts you have will also get the same treatment if/when they can identify them as being from a banned user

Based on my experience and research by trial and error (I graduated in computer science, I write code daily etc) this process is not automatic and is heavily dependent on reddit admins human input. They got tired very quickly and depend on mods reporting ban evasion to them a lot.

I agree, transparency is important to build the trust the platform needs to succeed. I wish admins would address the concerns raised so far before transparency tools are available.

body:
Yup, if poorly implemented, a rule against brigading might be worse than brigading itself. And your second point deals with a slippery slope that does happen all the time. (A third issue would be that brigading is about intentions - but it's hard to know the intentions of someone.)

I still think however brigades can be indirectly disallowed, by focusing on harmful (but hopefully more objective) things associated with them. [I'm actually thinking on such rules to suggest to the devs.]

parent.body:
The problem I see with disallowing brigading is that it opens up too many doors. Brigading itself is a negative, sure, but making significant efforts to dissuade it creates two things:

- An arms race. This is bad for everyone, bad actors included, but especially for us, with Ruggus' shaky servers.
- The justification to call one more thing bad behavior, and one more after that, which will turn Ruqqus into Reddit or centrist Reddit or Reddit Lite or w/e, This is proven human behavior, normal for moderation, and the way to avoid it is to keep these doors shut. 

Nobody wins.
parent.body_html:
The problem I see with disallowing brigading is that it opens up too many doors. Brigading itself is a negative, sure, but making significant efforts to dissuade it creates two things:

  • An arms race. This is bad for everyone, bad actors included, but especially for us, with Ruggus' shaky servers.
  • The justification to call one more thing bad behavior, and one more after that, which will turn Ruqqus into Reddit or centrist Reddit or Reddit Lite or w/e, This is proven human behavior, normal for moderation, and the way to avoid it is to keep these doors shut.

Nobody wins.

body:
Hey someone to engage with who sounds like they're giving this some thought. Thank you. 

I am worried about the slope. That is what happened on so many other platforms - whether you believe the racist conspiracy theories about *why* or not is frankly irrelevant - one change opens the door to another which opens the door to another, and so on. That along the way administration gets to make significant extra profit more often than not helps to grease the gears I am sure. 

The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave *another* of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

body:
>The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave another of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

I disagree it's a serious concern here. Even if hard to define and not yet in the rules, brigading *is* against the spirit of free discussion; so I believe the admins were on good faith, and banned people because of the stated principles (to preserve Ruqqus as a free speech platform).

About the racist conspiracy theories: I hear ya. Yeah, they're bullshit - but he who can silence bullshit can also silence the truth, once the truth is inconvenient. I think this slippery slope can be avoided by:

* focus should be always on the behaviour, not the opinion being voiced. 
* rule enforcement should be consistent. If I can't brigade to promote a discourse like "whites are being genocided!", then I can't brigade with *any* discourse, even if descriptively true or morally sound. (*cough cough* AHS getting a free brigade pass *cough cough*)
* rules should be as objective and clear-cut as possible, to reduce false positives and bias. Easier said than done.
body_html:
The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave another of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

I disagree it's a serious concern here. Even if hard to define and not yet in the rules, brigading is against the spirit of free discussion; so I believe the admins were on good faith, and banned people because of the stated principles (to preserve Ruqqus as a free speech platform).

About the racist conspiracy theories: I hear ya. Yeah, they're bullshit - but he who can silence bullshit can also silence the truth, once the truth is inconvenient. I think this slippery slope can be avoided by:

  • focus should be always on the behaviour, not the opinion being voiced.
  • rule enforcement should be consistent. If I can't brigade to promote a discourse like "whites are being genocided!", then I can't brigade with any discourse, even if descriptively true or morally sound. (cough cough AHS getting a free brigade pass cough cough)
  • rules should be as objective and clear-cut as possible, to reduce false positives and bias. Easier said than done.

Hey someone to engage with who sounds like they're giving this some thought. Thank you. 

I am worried about the slope. That is what happened on so many other platforms - whether you believe the racist conspiracy theories about *why* or not is frankly irrelevant - one change opens the door to another which opens the door to another, and so on. That along the way administration gets to make significant extra profit more often than not helps to grease the gears I am sure. 

The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave *another* of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

parent.body:
>The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave another of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

I disagree it's a serious concern here. Even if hard to define and not yet in the rules, brigading *is* against the spirit of free discussion; so I believe the admins were on good faith, and banned people because of the stated principles (to preserve Ruqqus as a free speech platform).

About the racist conspiracy theories: I hear ya. Yeah, they're bullshit - but he who can silence bullshit can also silence the truth, once the truth is inconvenient. I think this slippery slope can be avoided by:

* focus should be always on the behaviour, not the opinion being voiced. 
* rule enforcement should be consistent. If I can't brigade to promote a discourse like "whites are being genocided!", then I can't brigade with *any* discourse, even if descriptively true or morally sound. (*cough cough* AHS getting a free brigade pass *cough cough*)
* rules should be as objective and clear-cut as possible, to reduce false positives and bias. Easier said than done.

The admins here banning people without a clear rule violation is of serious concern if true, as it removes the whole point of the platform. I don't want to have to leave another of these sites, but someone else will pop up.

I disagree it's a serious concern here. Even if hard to define and not yet in the rules, brigading is against the spirit of free discussion; so I believe the admins were on good faith, and banned people because of the stated principles (to preserve Ruqqus as a free speech platform).

About the racist conspiracy theories: I hear ya. Yeah, they're bullshit - but he who can silence bullshit can also silence the truth, once the truth is inconvenient. I think this slippery slope can be avoided by:

  • focus should be always on the behaviour, not the opinion being voiced.
  • rule enforcement should be consistent. If I can't brigade to promote a discourse like "whites are being genocided!", then I can't brigade with any discourse, even if descriptively true or morally sound. (cough cough AHS getting a free brigade pass cough cough)
  • rules should be as objective and clear-cut as possible, to reduce false positives and bias. Easier said than done.

parent.body:
>any other/new accounts you have will also get the same treatment if/when they can identify them as being from a banned user

Based on my experience and research by trial and error (I graduated in computer science, I write code daily etc) this process is not automatic and is heavily dependent on reddit admins human input. I kept creating new accounts that would get suspended within the day, but as soon as I changed the pattern it stopped. They got tired very quickly and depend on mods reporting ban evasion to them a lot.

I agree, transparency is important to build the trust the platform needs to succeed. I wish admins would address the concerns raised so far before transparency tools are available.
parent.body_html:
any other/new accounts you have will also get the same treatment if/when they can identify them as being from a banned user

Based on my experience and research by trial and error (I graduated in computer science, I write code daily etc) this process is not automatic and is heavily dependent on reddit admins human input. I kept creating new accounts that would get suspended within the day, but as soon as I changed the pattern it stopped. They got tired very quickly and depend on mods reporting ban evasion to them a lot.

I agree, transparency is important to build the trust the platform needs to succeed. I wish admins would address the concerns raised so far before transparency tools are available.

body: They plan to add logs in the future, but I have noticed the admins acting much more rude and less transparent as of late. I think something might be wrong, as they were never like this before. The two main things that set them off right now are attempts to discuss 1) how they enforce the content policy and ban users, and 2) how they run the discord server (except with the mods in their private channel) and who is able to become a mod there. I don't know why this is, and it only started happening a few weeks ago.
